jSimPack

Class FutureEventList

  • java.lang.Object
    • jSimPack.FutureEventList

  • public class FutureEventList
extends java.lang.Object
    Dispatches abstract events that occur at discrete points in time. Events are dispatched in increasing order of their release time. The release time of an event is calculated when it is scheduled via #schedule(FutureEventListener,long,Object). Each event is associated with an FutureEventListener that takes an arbitrary action when the event occurs. While an FutureEventListener is processing an event, it can freely add further events to, or remove other events from, the event queue. A FutureEventList keeps track of the current time (as a long) in the simulation, so an event can never be added with a timestamp in the "past" (before the current time), but events can be removed before they are processed. The FutureEventList has a setting called realtimeRate. This allows the simulation to be clocked against the system clock so that simulation can be observed by the user. The system does not make a hard real-time guarantee of execution. It only guarantees that the simulator will execute no faster than the realtimeRate. The maximum rate can be set to POSITIVE_INFINITY for fastest execution, but the true maximum speed is limited by CPU speed. Simultaneous events are permuted randomly (according to the RandomSource passed in constructor). This models jitter in real systems and keeps periodic events that are synchronized (occur at the same time every period) from always executing in the same order. The event list also supports non-simulation events. The same event object (FutureEvent) is used, but they are scheduled in a separate queue. Non-simulation events are executed before any simulation events that occur at the same time. Non-simulation events are executed in such a way that they do not affect the random permutation of simulation events. Non-simulation events are used to implement breakpoints, which halt the simulation at a certain time. See SwingDisplay (which is used to restart the simulation and control the realtime rate) and SystemTimer, which also uses non-simulation events.

    • Method Detail

      • setEndTime

        public void setEndTime(SimTime time)
        Halt the simulator at a specified time
        Parameters:
        endTime - When to stop the simulator. This should be interpreted as clock time.

      • setRealtimeRate

        public void setRealtimeRate(double rate)
        Adjust the speed the simulator runs at. This is not a hard realtime guarantee, just a guarantee that the simulator will run no faster than the specified rate. The simulator can run as slow as is needed, but to run faster than realtime, the upper limit is based on the performance of the system and the java VM.
        Parameters:
        rate - the realtime rate

      • getRealtimeRate

        public double getRealtimeRate()
        Returns:
        the current realtime rate

      • schedule

        public FutureEvent schedule(FutureEventListener event,
                   SimTime timeInterval,
                   java.lang.Object data)
        Schedules the specified event to happen in the future. The event will happen timeInterval time ticks into the future. The specified data will be passed to FutureEventListener.eventReleased(Object) when the event occurs.
        Returns:
        A unique object that can be passed to #cancelEvent(Object, boolean) to identify this event.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if timeInterval is negative

      • scheduleNonsimulationEvent

        public FutureEvent scheduleNonsimulationEvent(FutureEventListener event,
                                     SimTime timeInterval,
                                     java.lang.Object data)
        Works just like scheduleEvent, but puts the event into the system queue (which are executed first and do not affect the random permutation of other events).

      • cancelNonsimulationEvent

        public void cancelNonsimulationEvent(FutureEvent event)
        Works jsut like cancelEvent but for nonsimulation events.
        Parameters:
        event -
        deleteNow -

      • cancelEvent

        public void cancelEvent(FutureEvent event)
        Cancel the event associated with label. If the event's release time coincides with the current simulation time, the event will be removed if and only if deleteNow is true.

      • runSimulationUntil

        public void runSimulationUntil(SimTime end)
        Start the simulator
        Parameters:
        howLong - how long to run the simulator. This value should be interpreted as an interval.

      • runSimulation

        public void runSimulation()
        Drives the simulation one step at a time until there are no more events to be released, the simulation time exceeds the specified ending time, or the simulation is ended immediately by calling endSimulation().

      • endSimulation

        public void endSimulation()
        Halt the simulator

      • stepSimulation

        public void stepSimulation()
        Move the simulation forward to the next event instant.

      • addBreakpoint

        public boolean addBreakpoint(SimTime breakpointTime)
        Add a breakpoint at the specified time. The breakpoint stops execution before any events that occur at that time.
        Parameters:
        breakpointTime - the absolute time at which to pause execution
        Returns:
        true if the breakpoint was added, false if there was already a breakpoint at that time.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the specified time is in the past or at the current simulation time

      • removeBreakpoint

        public boolean removeBreakpoint(SimTime breakpointTime)
        Remove a breakpoint
        Parameters:
        breakpointTime -
        Returns:

        public void addBreakpointListener(BreakpointListener l)
        Add an object that can respond when a breakpoint occurs.
        Parameters:
        l - The object that gets a callback when the breakpoint happens

        stop listeneing to breakpoint callbacks.
        Parameters:
        l -
        Returns:

        public boolean isBlocked()
        Returns:
        true if the simulation is temporarily halted.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] Args)

      • interleaveLock

        public void interleaveLock()
        call to acquire a lock on the event queue. While locked, the simulator will not step forward. This allows other threads (mainly the gui threads) to syncronize with the main simulation thread.

      • interleaveUnlock

        public void interleaveUnlock()
        Release the lock on the event queue.
